Feature: Is there weight-sensitive suprasegmental prominence, suprasegmental prominence can be loudness, duration, pitch, i.e. stress or tone phenomena?
Comment: the distribution of stress is still unclear

Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Comment: suffix -u 'DEF', could also refer to information status 'given'
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Form same as demonstratives, Form same as pronoun, Definiteness marking is done by an element with another function such as numeral classifiers, Definiteness marking is very restricted

Feature: Is an indefinite NP obligatorily accompanied by an indefinite (or non-specific) article?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, It exists but it is not obligatory, Same as numeral 'one'

Feature: Are there prenominal articles?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The definite article is prenominal, The indefinite article is prenominal, The definite article is a prefix, The indefinite article is a prefix

Feature: Are there postnominal articles?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The definite article is postnominal, The indefinite article is postnominal, The definite article is a suffix, The indefinite article is a suffix

Feature: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Mostly numeral-noun with a few exceptions, Mostly noun-numeral with a few exceptions, Either order occurs with any numeral

Feature: What is the order of demonstrative and noun in the NP?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Different demonstratives take different orders, There is free variation, Demonstrative construction has a form both before and after the noun, Demonstrative are treated as suffixes, Demonstrative are treated as prefixes

Feature: Are there 'discontinuous noun phrases'?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Is there a difference between the marking of NP coordination ('John and Mary went to market') and the marking of comitative phrases ('John went to market with Mary')?
Comment: but the 'and'-construction is derived from the 'with'-construction
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Is there a minimal-augmented system?
Is there a gender distinction in 3rd person pronouns (or demonstratives, if no 3rd person pronouns)?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Is there a dual (or unit augmented) in addition to a plural (or augmented) number category in pronouns?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Are 1st and 2nd persons conflated in any context?
Comment: 1EX and 2PL usually have the same form for verbal affixes.
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Same pronoun form covering both first and second person in some context, Person is marked on the verb and there is a context where first and second person are the same

Feature: Are 2nd and 3rd persons conflated in non-singular numbers?
Are person categories neutralized under some conditions?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Under negation, In a certain TAM context, Unclear whether the verb form counts as finite

Feature: Is there an opposition between three or more distance terms in the demonstrative system?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The distinction is distance from speaker versus hearer

Feature: Is elevation morphologically marked in demonstratives?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Is the opposition visible-non-visible marked on demonstratives?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The demonstrative classifier system is the same as another classifier system, Demonstratives agree with what is treated as noun classes

Feature: Are there declensions (partly) determined by number of the noun?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, There are different forms for marking number depending on the noun class, There are different forms for marking number which seem to be phonologically conditioned, The markers are adjacentbut not treated as bound

Feature: Are there declensions (partly) determined by gender of the noun?
Are there nouns which are suppletive for number?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Can singular number be marked on the noun itself?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Can dual number be marked on the noun itself?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Can plural number be marked on the noun itself?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is number marking prohibited on certain (types of) nouns?
Comment: to be defined further

Feature: Are there associative plurals?
Comment: Clan names with plural suffix, ex: Ata Wuwur-a 'person CLANNAME-PL' "the Wuwur people"
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Is there a productive morphologically marked Action/state nominalization (arrive/arrival)?
Comment: There are nominalization strategies through affixes (b-, -n-, N-) which are more general, similar to the use of Indonesian yang as nominalizer. But it is unclear how productive thery are.
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound, The marker is also a noun

Feature: Is there a productive morphologically marked Agentive nominalization (sing-er)?
Comment: There are nominalization strategies through affixes (b-, -n-, N-) which are more general, similar to the use of Indonesian yang as nominalizer. But it is unclear how productive thery are.
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound, The marker means 'person' or similar

Feature: Is there a productive morphologically marked Object nominalization (sing; song)?
Comment: There are nominalization strategies through affixes (b-, -n-, N-) which are more general, similar to the use of Indonesian yang as nominalizer. But it is unclear how productive thery are.
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound, The marker means 'thing' or similar

Feature: Are there noun classes/genders?
Is sex a relevant category in any noun class/gender system?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Nouns have semantic classification but the markers are not morphologically bound and are flexible, There is extensive classification but only to parts of the lexicon

Feature: Is shape a relevant category in any noun class/gender system?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Nouns have semantic classification but the markers are not morphologically bound and are flexible, There is extensive classification but only to parts of the lexicon

Feature: Is animacy (without reference to sex) a relevant category in any noun class/gender system?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Nouns have semantic classification but the markers are not morphologically bound and are flexible, There is extensive classification but only to parts of the lexicon

Feature: Is plant status a relevant category in any noun class/gender system?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Nouns have semantic classification but the markers are not morphologically bound and are flexible, There is extensive classification but only to parts of the lexicon

Feature: Does the language only have a gender distinction in 3rd person pronouns?
Is there concord within the NP, i.e. agreement of elements within the NP with the noun class of a noun?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, There are but they also have other functions such as classifying demonstratives, There are words with specific numeral meanings such as 'ten coconuts', There are different numerals used with different nouns

Feature: Are there possessive classifiers?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, There are but they also have other functions such as classifying demonstratives, There are words with specific possessive meaning such as 'my house', The classifiers reflect properties of the possessor rather than the possessum

Feature: Is alienable/inalienable a relevant distinction?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Are there different possessive constructions?
Comment: Alienable possessive constructions use a free possessor pronoun and cannot use a possessive suffix. Inalienable possessive constructions use a possessor suffix and an optional free pronoun.

Feature: Can possession be marked by a prefix?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Can possession be marked by a suffix?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Can possession be marked on the nominal possessor?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Can possession be marked on the nominal possessee?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: What is the order of possessor and possessed in the attributive possessive construction?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Pronouns use the opposite order

Feature: Are there different orders of elements in a possessive phrase for different classes of possession?
Comment: Only in case of a pronominal possessor, then the order of inalienable constructions is possessee-possessor, whereas the order of alienable constructions is possessor-possessee.

Feature: What is the counting system?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Comment: some do, some not
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Neither verbs nor adjectives receive marking, Some TAM and voice marking on verbs is not shared by adjectives

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Neither verbs nor adjectives receive marking, Some TAM and voice marking on verbs is not shared by adjectives

Feature: Is there case marking for core nominal NPs (i.e., S, A or O function)?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there case marking for core pronouns?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there case marking for oblique pronouns?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the noun but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Are there prepositions?
Comment: a general locational preposition la/lane and an object introducing preposition no derived from the verb -ora 'be with'
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are treated as bound to the noun, The adpositions are often also lexical nouns and verbs, Only one or very few

Feature: Are there postpositions?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are treated as bound to the noun, The adpositions are often also lexical nouns and verbs, Only one or very few

Feature: Are there adpositions to mark core NPs?
Comment: no is used to introduced the direct object of certain verbs
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are treated as bound to the noun, The adpositions are often also lexical nouns and verbs

Feature: Are there adpositions to mark oblique NPs?
Comment: lane (benefectee)
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are treated as bound to the noun, The adpositions are often also lexical nouns and verbs

Feature: Is there a distinction between locational and directional adpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound, Only one or very few

Feature: Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Comment: the use of the person/number suffixes lead for many verbs to a perfective meaning of the clause
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound, Only one or very few

Comment: infix -n- for nominalization
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, It is a type of reduplication, Some other doubt about why it is an infix

Feature: Is there present tense regularly morphologically marked on the verb?
Comment: no tense marking
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is described as non-past rather than specifically present, The marker conveys both tense and aspect, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there past tense regularly morphologically marked on the verb?
Comment: no tense marking
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there future tense regularly morphologically marked on the verb?
Comment: no tense marking
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is described as conveying non-past rather than specifically future, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Is a distinction between punctual/continuous aspect available as a morphological choice?

Feature: Is a distinction between realis/irrealis mood available as a morphological choice?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound, It is called 'realis'/'irrealis' by the grammar

Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound, There is a marker but it has other functions

Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Are person, number and any TAM category (i.e. 3 or more categories in all) marked by portmanteau morphemes on verbs?
Are categories such as person, number, gender related to a single participant discontinuously marked on a verb?
Comment: person/number is marked with a protemanteau morpheme

Feature: Are benefactive nominals marked on the verb?
Comment: A bound benefectee pronoun can be attached to the verb be 'give'. It has the same form as a direct object pronoun.
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Can instruments be marked on the verb?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Comment: They can be represented by the same person suffix (bound pronoun) as direct objects.

Feature: Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Only one or very few such as 'give'

Feature: Is negation marked morphologically on the verb?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the property word but not treated as morphologically bound

Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Are there suppletive verbs for number of participants?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Only one example

Feature: Are there suppletive verbs for tense or aspect?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, One or very few, Unclear whether the suppletive pattern is a conjugation class

Feature: Are there conjugation classes?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound, They are transitive versus intransitive verbs

Feature: Are there (several) verbs which can be used either transitively or intransitively with no morphological marking?
Comment: lêkot 'break', bêkat 'lift', lêngat 'fall'
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, There are only very few examples are or restricted in some way

Feature: Is there transitivising morphology (include clitics)?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there morphology (include clitics) to mark a reflexive action?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there morphology (include clitics) to mark a reciprocal action?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size, consistency or position of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?

Feature: Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, There is but it is not obligatory, There is but it is restricted such as in the past tense only, There is but it is a demonstrative

Feature: Are there serial verb constructions?
Comment: both verbs can take person marking (suffixes) but this marking can also be only on the second verb.
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Hard to distinguish from verb compounding, Limited to some verbs e.g. English 'go buy food'

Feature: Are there modal auxiliaries?
Comment: ma can have several meanings connected to modality (ex: volition, condition, obligation) but it still needs further investigation

Feature: Are there aspectual auxiliaries?
Comment: postverbal: kei 'perfective', kia 'inchoative', preverbal: nawa 'still, not yet'

Feature: Are there tense auxiliaries?
Is verb compounding a regular process?
Comment: constructions containing two verbs could be serial verb constructions or compounding, need to be investigated further
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Hard to distinguish from serial verb constructions

Feature: Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The noun appears adjacent to the verb but is not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there productive incorporation of non-nominal elements (adjectives, locatives, etc.) into verbs?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there one or more existential verb?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, It exists but is the same as the copula, It exists but also encodes position

Feature: Are there positional (classificatory) verbs?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, They are not fully obligatory

Feature: Is the verb 'give' morphologically peculiar (different from most other verbs)?
Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verbs in the language?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Pronouns have opposite order, Different depending on clause type or TAM etc., Occurs with a type of focus construction

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Pronouns have a different order, Different depending on clause type or TAM etc.

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Pronouns have a different order, Different depending on clause type or TAM etc.

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Pronouns have a different order, Different depending on clause type or TAM etc.

Feature: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Only in some type of subordinate clauses, Order is more restricted in main clauses, Order is more restricted in subordinate clauses

Feature: Do clausal objects occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Is constituent order fixed?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned that there is any variation, There is variation due to topicalisation and focus

Feature: Can negation be marked clause-finally?
Comment: si/sine
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Only in some sentences where a normally initial element such as the subject is not present, Negation is marked on the verb which appears clause-initially

Feature: Can negation be marked clause-initially?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Only in some sentences where a normally final element such as the direct object is not present, Negation is marked on the verb which appears clause-finally

Feature: Is there a difference between imperative and declarative negation?
Comment: bae 'prohibitive'
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Difference in word order, Difference in the form of the negator, Difference in the presence of a particular element which is not analysed as part of the negator

Feature: Are verbal and non-verbal predicates marked by the same negator?
Comment: take for non-verbal predicates
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, A special negator or negative form of the verb is used for existential meanings, A special negator or negative form of the copula is used with nominal predicates, A special negator or negative form of the copula is used with predicative adjectives, Other negative forms but which are discounted by the clarifying comment

Feature: Are S and O conflated morphologically in at least some basic constructions, i.e. simple main clauses?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Are S and A conflated morphologically in at least some basic constructions, i.e. simple main clauses?
Comment: S and A both take consonant final noun forms when occuring without attribute
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Are S and O conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. acting as syntactic pivot?
Are S and A conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. acting as syntactic pivot?
Do S and O operate in the same way, and differently from A, for the purpose of any syntactic construction?
Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The experiencer is expressed as an object, Only for mental states and emotions, There are verbs with unusual case frames but not necessarily controlled versus uncontrolled

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked passive construction?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked antipassive?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked inverse?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The marker is adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Is there clause chaining?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, Hard to distinguish from serial verb constructions

Feature: Is there a morphologically-marked switch reference system?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, There is a marker adjacent to the verb but not treated as morphologically bound

Feature: Are causatives formed by serial verb constructions?
Comment: ?? With -êr 'make'

Feature: Is there tail-head linkage?
Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned

Feature: Are verbs reduplicated?
Comment: to intensify the meaning

Feature: Are nouns reduplicated?

Comment: adejctives can be reduplicated to intensify the meaning

How many genders/noun classes are there?

Comment: The matrilateral cross-cousins (children of the mother's brother) are called opo (for males) / bibi (for females). The other cousins are called in the same way as siblings.
